--- title: "Efficiently Cleaning and Labelling Data Columns with `thekidsbiostats`" author: "Zac Dempsey, Dr Robin van de Meeburg" format: html: code-fold: true tabset: true toc: true toc-location: left date: "2026-02-12" categories: - R - Data cleaning - Package draft: true css: _extensions/html/styles.css editor_options: chunk_output_type: inline execute: echo: false warning: false fig-align: center fig-format: png --- ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="false"} library(thekidsbiostats) # install with install.packages("thekidsbiostats", repos = "the-kids-biostats.r-universe.dev") ``` ::: # Overview Datasets rarely come with cleaned, tidy formatting in their column names. Therefore, it is common practice to rename the original column names to something more syntactic, code-friendly names (i.e., unique, lower-case names with no spaces or special characters). Alongside code-friendly columns, it is also often useful to store *label attributes*, which provide clean, human-readable versions labels for each code-friendly variable for use in analytical reports, tables and figures. While a variety of functions for *renaming columns* (e.g., `dplyr::rename()`) and *applying labels* (e.g., using the [`labelled`](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/labelled/index.html) or [`Hmisc`](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/Hmisc/index.html) packages) exist, a reasonable amount of leg work is still needed before such functions can be applied. This post will demonstrate how [`thekidsbiostats`](https://github.com/The-Kids-Biostats/thekidsbiostats) can be used to streamline and expedite the process of standardising and labelling columns. Specifically, the following functions will be introduced: + [`make_column_dict()`](https://the-kids-biostats.github.io/thekidsbiostats/reference/make_column_dict.html)–--create a copy-pasteable column dictionary template. + [`update_columns()`](https://the-kids-biostats.github.io/thekidsbiostats/reference/update_columns.html)–--rename and label columns using a column dictionary. # Motivating Example As an example, let's point to the `data_patient` dataset, an example housed within the package: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="false"} data(data_patient, package = "thekidsbiostats") ``` ::: Previewing this dataset: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: Immediately, we see that the column headers are not formatted in a very nice way. The column headers contain (any combination of): + Categorical variable coding, + Full questions, + Spacing, + Inconsistent letter capitalisation, + Punctuation (parentheses, equals signs, questions marks, dashes, slashes). The spaces and punctuation in these column names require us to use backticks (``) to avoid R interpreting these symbols literally. Beyond visually looking messy, it can also be time consuming and tricky to reference these column names when attempting to use them in operations. For example, using the original column names, let's implement two trivial manipulations/changes to the data: ::: panel-tabset ## i) Calculate BMI ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="false"} data_patient$bmi <- data_patient$`WHAT IS YOUR CURRENT WEIGHT? (kg)` / (data_patient$`WHAT IS YOUR HEIGHT? (cm)` / 100.0)^2 ``` ::: ## ii) Re-Code `Sex` Recode the Sex column by replacing 0/1 with Male/Female, as defined in the existing column header. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="false"} data_patient$`Sex (0=Male, 1=Female)` = case_when( data_patient$`Sex (0=Male, 1=Female)` == 0 ~ "Male", data_patient$`Sex (0=Male, 1=Female)` == 1 ~ "Female", TRUE ~ NA_character_ ) ``` ::: ::: ::: column-margin Clearly, coding each of these changes are cumbersome and time intensive, and can restrict the readability of our code. ::: Functions such as `janitor::clean_names()` can be very useful for standardising such column names into syntactic names. However, this approach is still imperfect, and the resulting names may remain just as problematic (as seen below). ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="false"} colnames(janitor::clean_names(data_patient[6])) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "do_you_currently_smoke_any_form_of_tobacco_products_including_cigarettes_cigars_or_pipes_on_a_regular_basis" ``` ::: ::: ::: column-margin The "cleaned" version of this column name simply omits spaces and punctuation, and is still far too long. ::: ## Step 1: Create Data Dictionary ::: callout-important Naively renaming columns for easy manipulation in code risks dropping potentially useful information contained in the original column name (e.g., units and symbols). Ideally, we want to (i) rename the columns, and (ii) simultaneously retain human-readable labels for presentation/reporting. Our solution to this is therefore to manually set up a dictionary that maps the **old column names** to **newly formatted column names** as well as **apply label attributes**. ::: The `make_column_dict()` function facilitates this process by creating a ready-to-fill template based on the original column names in the data. For example: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="false"} dict <- make_column_dict(data = data_patient, auto_clean = TRUE) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` dict_patient <- tribble( ~old, ~new, ~label, 'Patient ID#', 'patient_id_number', '', 'DOB [YYYY-MM-DD]', 'dob_yyyy_mm_dd', '', 'Sex (0=Male, 1=Female)', 'sex_0_male_1_female', '', 'WHAT IS YOUR HEIGHT? (cm)', 'what_is_your_height_cm', '', 'WHAT IS YOUR CURRENT WEIGHT? (kg)', 'what_is_your_current_weight_kg', '', 'Do you currently smoke any form of tobacco products, including cigarettes, cigars, or pipes, on a regular basis?', 'do_you_currently_smoke_any_form_of_tobacco_products_including_cigarettes_cigars_or_pipes_on_a_regular_basis', '', 'bp (mmHg)', 'bp_mm_hg', '', 'Cholesterol / mmolL', 'cholesterol_mmol_l', '', 'bmi', 'bmi', '', ) ``` ::: ::: ::: column-margin The output of `make_column_dict` is a `tribble`---a *row-wise* data-frame object which allows one to more easily visualise the format of the table. ::: We can either directly add to, or modify, the `dict` object (as assigned above) or copy-paste the output into our code and modify the new column names and labels as needed (as done below): ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="false"} dict_patient <- tribble( ~old, ~new, ~label, 'Patient ID#', 'id', 'Patient ID', 'DOB [YYYY-MM-DD]', 'dob', 'Date of Birth', 'Sex (0=Male, 1=Female)', 'sex', 'Sex', 'WHAT IS YOUR HEIGHT? (cm)', 'height_cm', 'Height (cm)', 'WHAT IS YOUR CURRENT WEIGHT? (kg)', 'weight_kg', 'Weight (kg)', 'Do you currently smoke any form of tobacco products, including cigarettes, cigars, or pipes, on a regular basis?', 'current_smoking', 'Current tobacco consumption', 'bp (mmHg)', 'bp_mmhg', 'BP (mmHg)', 'Cholesterol / mmolL', 'cholesterol_mmol_l', 'Cholesterol (mmolL)', 'bmi', 'bmi', "BMI (kg/m^2)" ) ``` ::: ::: column-margin This `tribble` has been manually modified with "clean" column names and variable labels. Additionally, a row for the derived `bmi` variable has been included. ::: Alternatively, we can also write this file (e.g., csv, rds, xlsx) to our machine, by specifying `file`: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="false"} make_column_dict(data = data_patient, auto_clean = TRUE, file = "colnames.csv") ``` ::: And then read the csv back in after new column names and labels have been added: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="false"} dict_patient <- readr::read_csv(file = "colnames.csv") ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: ## Step 2: Apply column dictionary Now that we have defined the column dictionary above, we can simply use the `update_columns()` function to apply these changes in a single line. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="false"} data_clean <- update_columns( data_patient, dict = dict_patient, old = "old", # Name for *old* column names in `dict_patient` (default) new = "new", # Name for *new* column names in `dict_patient` (default) label = "label" # Label attribute for each variable (default) ) ``` ::: ::: column-margin The arguments `old`, `new`, `label` must correspond to the column names of the data dictionary object. By default, the names assigned in `make_column_dict()` are assumed. If the data dictionary uses different header names, these must be explicitly specified in `update_columns()`. ::: ## Previewing Output Previewing this "cleaned" dataset: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: # Closing comments Overall, the `make_column_dict()` and `update_columns()` functions from our package offer an efficient solution for transforming and labelling datasets with problematic column headers. More concise column names are easier to work with and enhance the readability/tractability of code, while user-defined labels allow users to easily produce more polished and publication-ready outputs.
